title: Boston couple’s wedding disrupted by blizzard — they got married anyway
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Maddie McNamara and Drew Baker switched their wedding venue to Newbury Hotel suite due to a Boston blizzard.
Their original Boston Public Library ceremony was canceled as severe weather forced vendors to back out and travel became unsafe.
The couple embraced the blizzard by taking photos in wedding attire on Newbury Street, highlighting their joyful attitude.

title: Dave Epstein: How long will it take for all this snow to melt?
author: David Epstein
bullets: Eastern Massachusetts has high snow levels; Providence recorded over 40 inches post-storm.
Above-freezing temperatures and strong sun will gradually melt the snow, reducing risks of flooding.
March 20 marks a likely transition from wintry conditions, with faster melting on south-facing slopes.

title: After calling police, Conn. man kills terminally ill wife and then himself
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: John Ezzell called 911 claiming he would kill his terminally ill wife, Christine, and then himself.
Police found John and Christine Ezzell dead with gunshot wounds in their Plainfield, Conn. home.
The incident was isolated, posing no public threat, and is under investigation by the medical examiner.

title: Derrick White, Celtics blow out Suns in second half, win fourth straight: 7 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: Derrick White scored 22 points and provided a game-high eight assists in the Celtics' 97-81 win over the Suns.
The Celtics' defense excelled in the third quarter with a 30-11 scoreline, including a 16-0 run.
Neemias Queta impressed with a 14-point, 13-rebound double-double, enhancing his role in the Celtics' starting lineup.

title: Recent homes sales in Greater Boston (Feb. 25)
author: The Boston Globe
bullets: High-priced home sales in Boston include a $14 million condo at 1 Dalton St.
In Beverly, two properties on Scott St. and Cabot St. sold for $6 million each.
Belmont's 200 Claflin St. sold for $2.3 million with 3 bedrooms and 2 baths.

title: How long will Mass. residents have to wait until their power is restored?
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Eversource and National Grid are working to restore power after a blizzard caused over 100,000 outages in Eastern Massachusetts.
National Grid aims to restore power to all customers by Wednesday midnight, while Eversource warns some may wait several days.
High winds and blizzard conditions hindered power restoration efforts, affecting areas hardest hit such as Cape Cod and the Islands.

title: 15 prospects Patriots fans should know entering the 2026 NFL Combine
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: The Patriots hold 11 picks, including the 31st overall, for the 2026 NFL Draft.
Eliot Wolf highlights edge defender as a key area needing improvement for the Patriots.
Prospects KC Concepcion, Zion Young, and Kenyon Sadiq are potential targets for roster upgrades.

title: Malden school employee on leave after alleged ‘serious incident’ involving high school student
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Malden police investigate a 'serious incident' involving a school employee and high school student; details remain undisclosed.
The district placed the Linden STEAM Academy employee on leave as a cautionary measure while police investigate the allegations.
No arrests or charges have been made; the incident reportedly occurred outside working hours, according to Superintendent Timothy Sippel.

title: These Mass. schools are closed for Wednesday, Feb. 25
author: Audrey Cooney
bullets: Massachusetts schools on the South Coast and South Shore closed due to a three-foot snowstorm.
Districts including Brockton, Quincy, and Plymouth among those closed on Wednesday, Feb. 25.
Delayed openings reported in Canton, King Philip Regional, Sharon, Walpole, and Wrentham.

title: MBTA to (mostly) resume normal weekday service after historic blizzard
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: MBTA plans to resume normal weekday service for most lines by Wednesday after historic blizzard in Greater Boston area.
Fall River/New Bedford Commuter Rail line to operate on modified weekday schedule due to severe storm impact.
MBTA advises riders to allow extra travel time and stay updated via T-Alerts and the MBTA Go app.
